verses.text: The words of Agur son of Jakeh, the oracle. This man declared to Ithiel, to Ithiel and to Ucal:
verses.comment: Proverbs 30 is unique for attributing its content to Agur, likely a sage outside of Israel. The repetition of 'Ithiel' could suggest emphasis, or address to multiple listeners.

verses.text: Surely I am more stupid than any man, and do not have the understanding of a man.
verses.comment: Agur speaks with humility, echoing Psalm 73:22 and showing that wisdom begins with recognizing one's limitations.

verses.text: I have not learned wisdom, nor do I have knowledge of the Holy One.
verses.comment: This humility anticipates the teaching that true wisdom is revealed—not earned—reflecting the idea that faith seeks understanding.

verses.text: Who has gone up to heaven and come down? Who has gathered the wind in his fists? Who has bound the waters in a cloak? Who has established all the ends of the earth? What is his name, and what is his son's name? Surely you know!
verses.comment: Verse 4 contains a profound mystery later hinted in the New Testament (see John 3:13), offering a subtle pointer towards the revelation of the Son and the doctrine of Christ's divinity.

verses.text: Every word of God is pure; he is a shield to those who take refuge in him.
verses.comment: This verse affirms the trustworthiness of God's word—a theme central to the Christian faith and guiding the Church's interpretation.

verses.text: Do not add to his words, or he will rebuke you and prove you a liar.
verses.comment: This warning not to add to God's words prefigures later warnings found in Revelation, affirming the importance of faithful transmission and tradition.

verses.text: Two things I ask of you; do not withhold them from me before I die:
verses.comment: A personal prayer, expressing reliance on God and humble petition.

verses.text: Keep falsehood and lies far from me; give me neither poverty nor riches; feed me with the food that is necessary for me,
verses.comment: The desire for 'daily bread' here is echoed in the Lord's Prayer, emphasizing moderation, contentment, and trust.

verses.text: lest I be full and deny you and say, 'Who is the Lord?' or lest I be poor and steal and profane the name of my God.
verses.comment: Agur seeks a balance of life that leads to holiness rather than sin, echoing biblical teaching that our actions reflect our relationship with God.

verses.text: Do not slander a servant to his master, or he will curse you, and you will be held guilty.
verses.comment: A warning against bearing false witness. Respect for others, even the least, is a recurring biblical principle.

verses.text: There are those who curse their fathers and do not bless their mothers.
verses.comment: A reminder of the Fourth Commandment and the continuing obligation to honor parents—an obligation carried into Christian moral teaching.

verses.text: There are those who are pure in their own eyes, yet are not cleansed from their filthiness.
verses.comment: Self-righteousness without actual repentance is condemned, pointing toward the need for inner purification.

verses.text: There are those—how lofty are their eyes, how their eyelids are lifted up!
verses.comment: Pride is a central vice condemned in Scripture and is to be avoided by all who seek holiness.

verses.text: There are those whose teeth are swords, whose jaws are knives, to devour the poor from the earth and the needy from among mankind.
verses.comment: This verse denounces oppression of the poor—a constant prophetic and apostolic concern.

verses.text: The leech has two daughters: 'Give! Give!' they cry. There are three things that are never satisfied; four never say, 'Enough':
verses.comment: Leeches, as symbols of greed, illustrate the endless appetite of sinful desire. The numerical saying introduces a poetic list.

verses.text: Sheol, the barren womb, the earth that is never satisfied with water, and fire that never says, 'Enough!'
verses.comment: Desires contrary to God's order are insatiable, much like Sheol or the grave. The imagery extends to spiritual truths about moderation.

verses.text: The eye that mocks a father and scorns to obey a mother—ravens of the valley will pluck it out and young eagles will eat it.
verses.comment: Rebellion against parents is shown as deeply serious, reinforcing respect and submission as virtues.

verses.text: There are three things that are too wonderful for me; four that I do not understand:
verses.comment: A poetic sequence showing that many of God's works are mysterious, inviting awe and humility.

verses.text: the way of an eagle in the sky, the way of a serpent on a rock, the way of a ship on the high seas, and the way of a man with a maiden.
verses.comment: The list highlights the mysteries of creation and human love—realities that bear spiritual as well as literal meaning.

verses.text: This is the way of an adulterous woman: she eats and wipes her mouth and says, 'I have done no wrong.'
verses.comment: Moral blindness is condemned. There is a need for both interior and exterior acknowledgment of sin and repentance.

verses.text: Under three things the earth trembles; four it cannot bear up:
verses.comment: The earth's order is depicted as shaken by certain injustices, signaling the seriousness of sin.

verses.text: a servant when he becomes king, a fool when he is filled with food,
verses.comment: Reversal of rightful order promotes chaos and is cautioned against in both Testaments.

verses.text: an unloved woman when she gets a husband, and a maidservant who displaces her mistress.
verses.comment: Disorder in relations points to the value of proper order and faithfulness, which God upholds.

verses.text: Four things on the earth are small, but they are exceedingly wise:
verses.comment: God imparts wisdom even to the lowly, reflecting the theme of divine providence.

verses.text: the ants are a people not strong, yet they prepare their food in the summer;
verses.comment: Diligence and foresight, as seen in God's creatures, are virtues to emulate.

verses.text: the rock badgers are a people not mighty, yet they make their homes in the cliffs;
verses.comment: The example calls for seeking security in God, not human strength.

verses.text: the locusts have no king, yet all of them march in rank;
verses.comment: Order and unity without visible leadership point to a mystery—anticipating the spiritual unity intended for the faithful.

verses.text: the lizard you can take in your hands, yet it is in kings' palaces.
verses.comment: Seemingly insignificant creatures reach the highest positions—a lesson in humility and providential exaltation.

verses.text: There are three things that stride with stately pace, four that are stately in their walk:
verses.comment: Certain creatures reflect the beauty and order of God's creation.

verses.text: the lion, mighty among beasts, which does not turn back before any;
verses.comment: The lion, a symbol for kings and for Christ (see Rev. 5:5), is here pictured as fearless and kingly.

verses.text: the strutting rooster, the he-goat, and a king whose army is with him.
verses.comment: Each symbol points to strength, order, and rightful leadership—all established by God.

verses.text: If you have played the fool and exalted yourself, or if you have plotted evil, put your hand on your mouth.
verses.comment: A call to humility and repentance—one must acknowledge sin and practice restraint.

verses.text: For if you churning milk produces butter, and twisting the nose brings forth blood, so the pressing of anger produces strife.
verses.comment: Final proverbial warning: actions have consequences, and uncontrolled passion leads to discord—a central theme in Christian life and teaching.
